instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message:
Sort of stumped by an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> right now. Board came in with a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, which I located to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced those components, and short is gone, and board will power on from battery, but I have no green light and I'm missing basically everything (3v42, ppbus, etc). My <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is essentially 0v, but no short is present. I'm getting the feeling that I have a critical resistor that's blown or something, but I can't find it. I checked all resistors around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, and they all measure out fine. Also checked <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>, etc. I tried to start "from the top", but with 0v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and no short, I don't really know where else to go.

Any ideas where to go from here? All help appreciated.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message: Hey Louis, thanks! I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> as part of my troubleshooting, and still the exact same issues. I'll replace it again to be sure (at least my thinking was in the right direction!). Will do that now then update.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and no change; unless both <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>'s I've used were bad, I think the issue may lie somewhere else. Any ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message:
I don't have an identical board here to check, but can someone check the diode readings below for <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and compare?

Diode readings <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>:

Pin 1/2 = .538 (confirmed continuity to <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>)
Pin 4/5 = 1.7 (confirmed continuity to <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>)
Pin 3 = OL
Pin 6 = OL

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message: remove the DC in fuse and apply 18.5v to the dc in fuse from an external power supply, then plug the magsafe in and tell me what behavior you get.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message:
Thanks, Louis; I removed the fuse and injected 18.45v at 2 amps, and immediately something "popped". I don't see any damage to anything I can tell, but I did smell that distinct "burnt electronics" smell, so something definitely bit the dust immediately. Didn't see any smoke, and can't locate the component visually or via smell, but I do notice that my <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> got very hot as well.

Thinking I'll need to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> all together again?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board, No Green Light, Powers from Battery
threads.message: Got this one solved, I think; I decided to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> all together again, and found a cap that was cracked in the process. Not sure which it was, the cap or one of the FETs, but I have green light and fan spin with charger now! Thank goodness; I'm going to get this guy into a test case and hopefully it will not have any other issues. I'll post back for sure once it passes everything, but did want to post this update now. Thank you Louis! I believe it may have been <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> after all.
